NEWS BITES

Ireland’s Home Values Stop Increasing After Six-Year Run After six years of real estate growth, home price appreciation in Ireland has effectively stalled, due in large part to the Brexit fallout. The third quarter average price stands at €257,000 (US$282,400) after falling by €4,000 from the second quarter. The average price now stands 57% above where the market bottomed out in 2013, through it’s still a full 30% below the pre-recession high in 2007. World Property Journal

U.A.E. Rental Returns Outpace Other Housing Markets Owners of rental properties in the U.A.E. will find themselves able to get much stronger returns than they would in places like Thailand or Malaysia. Those in the industry say owners can get returns of up to 7.5%, while investors in nearby countries only see around 2% to 3% returns. Relatively flexible immigration policies, the upcoming Expo 2020 and low interest are all encouraging growth in UAE’s real estate market. Khaleej Times

Foreign Interest in Portugal Is Pricing Out Locals Portugal’s rising profile as an international real estate hotspot is making it more difficult for local residents to find housing. Beneficial tax policies and investor visa programs have drawn in foreign nationals from the U.S., Canada, Spain, Greece and elsewhere. Prices, meanwhile, rose 9.2% in the first quarter. South China Morning Post

American Home Equity Value Rises Increases in home equity are giving American owners more value. The average owner’s equity increased by 4.8% year-over-year in the second quarter of 2019. The number of mortgaged properties with negative equity dropped 7% between the first and second quarter to hit 3.8% of all mortgaged homes. Fewer owners, however, are cashing out, with only $54 billion in equity taken out in the first quarter, the lowest amount in the past four years. CNBC
